Award.AwardTitle: BRAID 2.0: Bringing Relationships Alive through Interdisciplinary Discourse

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The BRAID 2.0 project is: (i) creating intensely BRAIDed clusters of freshman undergraduate science and technology courses and (ii) pursuing a longitudinal research study of both the change in attitudes and understanding of students and faculty over time. Over four years the project is generating five sets of multiple curricular BRAIDs, that explicitly tie the overlapping topic content of three disciplinary courses, e.g. Math, Chemistry and History of Science, with a small additional weekly seminar class that emphasizes interdisciplinary discussions between students and all three faculty. In research, this project employs a longitudinal study tracking the performance of students who pass through the BRAID curriculum (and controls, i.e. students who do not participate) as they continue in their upper-level courses and progress to graduation. We expect the participating students to show improved interdisciplinary thinking skills and improved performance in subsequent upper-level courses where topics become quite interdisciplinary. These gains during the BRAID experience and following in the tracking years are being examined via expert interviews, surveys and course performances. In addition we are also studying change in faculty expertise and attitudes over time. In this project we are gathering data to strategically contribute to research on undergraduate learning of science. These results have direct applications for improving educational practice in undergraduate science and technology courses. They will impact our understanding of how this experience catalyzes change in students' attitudes and understanding, as well as in that for participating faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the last 20+ years, national reports have been calling for new and better teaching approaches at universities and experts have evidence that about half of the students who start college excited about learning science are disappointed and even drop it as their major. This loss of talent occurred not only among the most highly qualified college freshmen but was also high among women and minorities. Yet, science teaching at the university remains slow to change, while today’s employers join the call for change and demand even more talented workers than the USA is currently producing. Employers not only want to hire talented college graduates who know their major but also know how to do math, be logical thinkers, write well, and if you are a biology major who also understands chemistry and physics, maybe understands computer code, you are hired immediately! We believe “future” scientists will need to understand more than their “first” discipline (like their first language) to be highly successful. Therefore, innovative teaching approaches are needed to educate our students and prepare them to become scientists.

 

We spent several years developing and testing out new “BRAID” classes that included multiple topics rather than just one (mixtures of Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, Physics and HPS[1]). These were taken by freshman and sophomore-year college students at Michigan State University (MSU). Students who took these classes were interviewed regularly and we tracked how well they did in courses taken after the BRAID class.

 

During this grant, we ran a formal research program that implemented our “high dose” model of BRAIDing which involved three faculty from different fields together with students in a small classroom to debate and discuss connections between their three different fields (like biology, chemistry and history). Our findings indicate that this explicit discussion and debate about the connections found in real world examples between a handful of students and several faculty together in a small classroom resulted in a transformative learning experience for students.

 

Impact on students

The interviews with students who took “high dose” classes showed very positive results. In the seminar, the students met once a week with the faculty for the three courses and talked for an hour about a variety of topics that could span all three disciplines. This lower stress environment, where students were able to share their own ideas and (perhaps equally importantly) join faculty from different disciplines in debate, allowed students to practice and gain confidence in creating connections between disciplines.  As one student said during a reflective interview, the best aspect of the BRAID seminar was:

 

“Well it was with the connections because sometimes they’re really hard to see when you’re just in your separate classes.  You don’t really think about the HPS aspect of chemistry or something like that or the biological aspect but with those discussions we got to pick a topic and then see each way that it connects with different things.  Then since you see those connections now then you can go to class and then you can also start making connections by yourself.”
